author: Christine Delsol
title: Old Monterey gardens host plein-air weekend
text:
On-air shooter threatened to make 'headlines,' showed anger Page 1 of 1 
Local artists will set up their easels in and around the gardens gracing early 19th century adobes and other historic sites in Old Monterey during Art in the Gardens. Visitors can watch the artists paint and draw on Saturday, then return Sunday to consider buying one of the finished works. Docents and gardeners will be on hand to provide information on development of the gardens, which reflect the tastes and available materials of their time. Maps and information will be available in the Sensory Garden at Casa de Oro, where the exhibition and sale will also take place. 
Vitals: Sept. 12-13, 11 a.m.-4 p.m. Free. Scott and Olivier streets, Monterey, (831) 241-5504, www.oldmontereyfoundation.org. 
Petaluma’s river of beer: Downtown Petaluma’s waterfront promenade will host a phalanx of tasting tents as more than 20 local breweries, including the highly praised Lagunitas, Petaluma Hills and Hen House , set up for the Petaluma River Craft Beer Festival. Food and live music will add to the fun, and the price of admission includes a souvenir beer glass. Proceeds benefit river projects and local nonprofits. Sept. 12, 1-5 p.m. $40 in advance, $20 designated driver. (707) 762-2785, www.petalumarivercraftbeerfest.org. 
Revolution in Nevada City: Independence Day might get all the hoopla, but Nevada City celebrates the signing of the U.S. Constitution, nine years later, with equal fervor. In addition to a living history Revolutionary War encampment, the small Gold Country town’s Constitution Day parade features such favorites as the Ophir Prison Marching Kazoo Band and the Famous Marching Presidents of Nevada City, which portrays every U.S. president. Sept. 12-13, 10 a.m.-6:30 p.m. 
(parade 2 p.m. Sunday). Free admission; small charge for some activities. (530) 265-2692 or (800) 655-6569, www.nevadacitychamber.com.
